diagnosed a good five to six years
before I recognized a change in his
smell it's quite a musky spell but as he

just thought it was an increase in sweat
but he'd already got the tiredness by
then and it wasn't until we moved back
to Paris that when I was in a room with
other Parkinson's people people with
Parkinson's and that I realized they
also had this mouth so it's a musky
smell that you that you identify with
yes and had you ever thought that you
had a particularly sensitive yes Melanie
I did have a sensitive sense of smell
yes because I could smell things that
other people didn't well professor Alfa
help us with the science behind this so
smell is molecules that move through the
air we call them volatile molecules that
means they easily get out of the
surfaces skin and move through the air
and that's what we smell so what we do
is we detect molecules so joy approached
our team and said can you tell us can
you tell me what I smell and and we can
so we have noses they're somewhat more
sensitive than than Joy's nose but they
can't discriminate as well so what we do
is we what we're measuring is something
called a metabolites metabolites are
molecules that are excreted all over our
body and and in all of our biological
processes and the subject we used to
study them is called metabolomics and we
look at all of the molecules that come
off so when we started to look into the
smell we did a study where we took some
people some with Parkinson's and some
without and made them wear t-shirts we
then gave the t-shirts to joy to
distinguish between them and she was
100% right every time every time we then
took these t-shirts and we extracted the
molecules from them and we looked at the
different molecules and we also could
distinguish a different fingerprint or
signature a different set of molecules
from people with Parkinson's of people
without
